title: Review: Amy Schumer livens it up with Apollo special on HBO
text:
Amy Schumer: Live At The Apollo
What: Emmy-winning comedian does a stand-up special, directed by Chris Rock and taped at New York’s iconic theater.
When: 10 p.m. Saturday.
Where: HBO.
After a riff about women’s underwear early in her performance at the famed Apollo Theater in New York, Amy Schumer looks at the audience and says, “I don’t know why the guys are grossed out?”
Perhaps some of the women were, too, but, really, no one should be.
Yes, Schumer’s often self-deprecating humor is filled with racy material and stories about bodily functions, but since the comedian’s stand-up special, “Live at the Apollo,” is on HBO let’s hope you are old enough not to be grossed out.
What sets the comedian apart from her male and female counterparts is that she scores laughs mostly from saying the outrageous so matter-of-fact-ly, even sweetly. Nothing seems out of bounds to her, but she doesn’t go out of her way to find something offensive, either.
In the special, directed by Chris Rock and taped last May, Schumer mocks being labeled a “sex comic” because she’s “a girl,” and then wryly reminds the audience “we have all been disgusting.”
That’s what makes her relatable to everyone. While Schumer slyly plays off of her own girly persona, she also is willing to take just enough time to make a joke real — use the “cold hard facts,” as a sports channel says.
“I think sex is explained incorrectly as far as men’s and women’s roles,” Schumer notes.
She brings that home later when she talks about woman enjoying sex. When she asks the audience if they knew any sex acts that would please a woman, I think she proves it when a young man answers.
While Schumer’s act was hilarious (we’ll let her tell the jokes), that moment (not repeatable in a family newspaper) was un-be-liev-able.
Where to watch
What: Emmy-winning comedian does a stand-up special, directed by Chris Rock and taped at New York’s iconic theater.
When: 10 p.m. Saturday.
Where: HBO.
